newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ's Morgan denies offering story for cash.
newsitem.headline: NZ's Morgan denies offering story for cash.

text.p: NZ First MP Tukoroirangi Morgan denied offering to sell his story to a television network for NZ$20,000 after both TV3 and TVNZ reported receiving approaches from a lawyer claiming to represent the MP.

New Zealand First leader Winston Peters met Morgan last night shortly after TV3 broadcast a taped conversation with Auckland solicitor Chris Reid, in which Reid claimed he represented Morgan and wanted to offer the network an "exclusive" interview.
Asked afterwards if it was true he had offered to sell his story, Mr Morgan said "No" before rushing into another meeting.
On the basis of Morgan's assurances, Peters also denied the charge, saying Reid had never been employed to represent Morgan.

"There is no basis to it. Mr Morgan does not have a lawyer called Mr Reid. He never gave any instructions to a lawyer called Mr Reid. Therefore, whatever actions were taken were not taken on Mr Morgan's authority and there the story ends," Peters told reporters.
Calls to Mr Reid's Auckland office were being intercepted by an answerphone last night and his cellphone was switched off.

Morgan's political career has been marred by revelations about thousands of dollars in salary and perks he received while working for publicly-funded Maori broadcaster Aotearoa Television Network last year. A Serious Fraud Office report on the company's affairs is due shortly.
On Three National News, presenter John Campbell said he received an approach from Mr Reid this afternoon in which Mr Reid offered an exclusive interview with Mr Morgan.
TVNZ presenter Paul Holmes later confirmed his Holmes show had also received an approach.
